column1: How many viewers will tune in to watch Sunday Night Football on 5 November 2017?
column5: ['Fewer than 14.5 million', 'Between 14.5 million and 15 million, inclusive', 'More than 15 million but less than 15.5 million', 'Between 15.5 million and 16 million, inclusive', 'More than 16 million']
column11: This question will be resolved using Nielsen's Fast National Ratings data as reported on The Futon Critic in the "Sunday's Broadcast Ratings" summary of 29 October 2017. Fast National Ratings are typically reported on the Monday following Sunday programming. This season's Fast National viewership numbers for Sunday Night Football are as follows: 10 September 2017: 21.559 million viewers (The Futon Critic) 17 September 2017: 18.460 million viewers (The Futon Critic) 24 September 2017: 14.537 million viewers (The Futon Critic) 1 October 2017: 14.009 million viewers (The Futon Critic) 8 October 2017: 14.853 million viewers (The Futon Critic) 15 October 2017: 14.423 million viewers (The Futon Critic) 22 October 2017: 16.741 million viewers (The Futon Critic) 29 October 2017: 12.666 million viewers The Futon Critic) NOTE: This is an experimental short-term question intended to serve as 'forecasting fodder.' The idea is to give forecasters a way to get scored quickly on questions that demand difficult, multifaceted analysis. Sunday Night Football viewership in any given week may be influenced by long-term trends (e.g. a move to streaming services), or circumstances specific to game day (who is playing, what competing programming will air), among other factors. Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: Total viewership tonight will be about 5%less than last week 12.666million it says. A Nothing burgergame tonight followed be an even bigger meh game on Monday night. Question: will their also be Monday night football questions? If so my estimate is about the same with a bigger 5-10%decline in viewership from last Monday (I know no one asked).

Adjusting again based on the recent tragedy in Texas, as that might affect the local markets in addition to the national markets trying to learn more about what happened. Plus, I'm not sure very many people are excited about the Raiders vs. Dolphins, except for fans and fantasy players, and maybe those who just have nothing else to watch.

With passing of Halloween, it's really fall, and that means football. Only 10% of Americans at best are principled to really boycott the NFL over the flag protest issue. The World Series is over and there's not a whole lot of competition. People might even tune in to see who takes the knee. So I expect better ratings than last week. I feel pretty good about the consensus here.
Moving forecast slightly closer to current consensus numbers

Now that the World Series is over and no college football on Sundays there will be some return to professional football. As the season wears on and great hockey and basketball games show up on Sundays then the NFL will find that many former fans are gone for good.
Re-run the model used for Wk8, changing Xs for OAK-MIA!

The October 22 bump was due to NE/ATL playing. Raiders last Sunday game on Sept 24 (14.5M). Dolphins historically do not bring viewership bumps. Base viewership at 14.5M. Account for 5% from base for general viewership decrease.

Ok. One more try at this. I attempted to solve one of the problems of using SMW rather than Futon. SMW seemed to have a significantly higher overall result pushing my numbers up meaningfully (and thus the SNF premium had to be adjusted down). There is now an explicit adjustment for the Futon results.

One hopes, more or less against hope, that amurricans are catching on that these players are not athletes in the sense that soccer or rugby or tennis or baseball or even cricket players are, but are more like weightlifters or sprinters--each one has to do only one thing pretty well but needn't bother with anything else, and each guy only works maybe 10 minutes a week anyway. Viewed this way, this so-called sport is actually pretty boring.

Generally agree with danbell7819's comments below. Tossing out the large opening week audience SNF is averaging just over 15 million viewers -- but trending below that in recent weeks. Not necessarily a 'marquee' game matchup for this Sunday. Oakland has lost 5 of its last 6 games. TV markets involved may be somewhat larger than last week's Pitt.-Detroit, but not markedly. (SF-Oak., # 6 -- but probably divided. Miami, #16 market, game is televised there.) Game is on at 5:20 PT in Oakland...can't say if positive or negative for viewership there. (Technically outside of 'prime time'..) End of DST means hours of darkness (outside) before game-time esp. in the eastern US. Could somewhat boost TV viewership.

This week's SNF match-up is between the Oakland Raiders (3-5) and the Miami Dolphins (4-3). Again, not necessarily a marquee match-up. However, there are some things that go in favor of a higher viewership this week. First, Oakland has a pretty loyal fan base (Pittsburgh last week also did, but had less viewership for other reasons in my opinion), so that should help. Second, there's no major programming to compete with. There's some NBA and NHL games, which will probably chip away at some viewership, but nothing on the basic cable channels which would draw viewership away. Third, last year's SNF match-up was OAK vs. KC, which garnered just over 15.3M viewers. Granted, that was a divisional match-up with playoff implications, so that likely bumped viewership higher. Finally, with the exception of some notable outliers, viewership has averaged around the 15M mark.
